Science.definition: A testable explanation for an observation that can be supported or refuted through experimentation.
A factor in an experiment that can change or be controlled.
The group in an experiment that does not receive the independent variable and is used for comparison.
A community of living organisms interacting with each other and with their physical environment.
The process by which plants use light energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen.
The process in which cells break down glucose and oxygen to release energy, carbon dioxide, and water.
A type of cell division that results in two identical daughter cells.
A type of cell division that produces four non-identical gametes (sex cells) with half the genetic information.
The molecule that carries genetic information in living organisms.
A molecule that carries out DNA instructions to produce proteins.
The smallest unit of an element that retains the properties of that element.
Two or more atoms that are chemically bonded together.
The force of attraction between objects with mass.
An observation that describes qualities or characteristics without using numbers.
An observation that uses numbers or measurements to describe what is observed.
The process by which organisms maintain stable internal conditions despite external changes.
The factor that is purposely changed in an experiment to test its effect.
The factor that is measured in an experiment and changes in response to the independent variable.
A systematic process of asking questions, forming hypotheses, conducting experiments, and drawing conclusions.
The theory explaining the movement of Earth's lithospheric plates and the activity at their boundaries.
The preserved remains, impression, or trace of an organism from the past.
The movement of energy from one object or system to another.
A change in the DNA sequence that can result in inherited variation.
Large molecules made of amino acids that perform essential functions in living cells.
A protein that speeds up chemical reactions in living organisms.
A structure made of different tissues working together to perform a specific function.
A group of similar cells working together to perform a function.
The outer boundary of a cell that controls what enters and exits.
The membrane-bound organelle containing DNA in a eukaryotic cell.
The organelle responsible for producing energy through cellular respiration.
The organelle in plant cells where photosynthesis occurs.
The process of oxygen intake and carbon dioxide release in organisms.
The movement of blood throughout the body via the cardiovascular system.
The growth response of plants toward or away from light.
The growth response of plants in relation to gravity.
The biological process by which organisms produce offspring.
The passing of traits from parents to offspring through genes.
One of the alternative forms of a gene for a specific trait.
The genetic makeup of an organism.
The observable characteristics of an organism determined by genotype and environment.
The permanent disappearance of a species from Earth.
The evolutionary process by which new species arise.
The wearing away of rock and soil by water, wind, or ice.
The breakdown of rocks and minerals by wind, water, temperature changes, or organisms.
The process of sediment being deposited in layers over time.
Rock formed from existing rock changed by heat and pressure deep in the Earth.
Rock formed from consolidated sediment layers compressed over time.
Rock formed from cooled and solidified magma or lava.
A naturally occurring solid with a definite chemical composition and orderly structure.
The continuous process of rock formation, destruction, and reformation.
A large ocean wave caused by sudden movement of the Earth's crust.
Sudden shaking of the Earth's crust caused by tectonic plate movement.
An opening in the Earth's crust where lava, ash, and gases erupt.
Molten rock beneath the Earth's surface.
Molten rock that has erupted onto the Earth's surface.
The outermost solid layer of the Earth.
The layer beneath the crust composed of hot rock.
The hot, dense center of the Earth.
The rigid outer layer of the Earth consisting of crust and upper mantle.
The layer of gases surrounding the Earth.
All life and habitats on Earth.
All water on and around the Earth.
A particle of light energy.
The distance between consecutive wave crests or troughs.
The number of waves passing a point per unit time.
Vibrations that travel through a medium as waves.
The perceived highness or lowness of a sound determined by frequency.
The maximum displacement of a wave from equilibrium, affecting loudness or brightness.
A curved transparent optical element that focuses or disperses light.
The bending of light when passing from one medium to another.
The bouncing back of light or sound from a surface.
The science of light and vision.
The range of all electromagnetic radiation from radio waves to gamma rays.
The energy an object possesses due to its motion.
The energy an object possesses due to its position or condition.
The study of heat and its relationship to mechanical energy.
The total heat content of a system.
A measure of disorder or randomness in a system.
A reaction that releases heat energy.
A reaction that absorbs heat energy.
A substance that participates in a chemical reaction.
A substance formed as a result of a chemical reaction.
The loss of electrons from an atom or molecule.
The gain of electrons by an atom or molecule.
A substance that speeds up a reaction without being consumed.
A state in which forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate.
A homogeneous mixture of a solute dissolved in a solvent.
The substance being dissolved in a solution.
The liquid medium in which a solute is dissolved.
The condition when a solution contains the maximum amount of dissolved solute.
The concentration of a solution expressed as moles of solute per liter.
A numerical scale from 0 to 14 measuring the acidity or alkalinity of a solution.
A solution that resists changes in pH when acids or bases are added.
A laboratory technique for determining the concentration of an acid or base.
The combining capacity of an element.
The number of protons in an atom, determining the element's identity.
The total number of protons and neutrons in an atom.
Atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.
An atom or molecule with a net electrical charge.
A positively charged ion.
A negatively charged ion.
A solid form with atoms arranged in an orderly repeating pattern.
A large molecule made of many repeating subunits called monomers.
The product of an object's mass and velocity.
The resistance of an object to changes in its motion.
The product of force and the time interval over which the force acts.
A force that causes rotation around a pivot point.
The force applied perpendicular to a surface per unit area.
The upward force exerted by a fluid on an object immersed in it.
The amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of one unit of mass by one degree.
The energy required to change the state of matter without changing temperature.
The direct change from solid to gas without passing through the liquid phase.
The direct change from gas to solid without passing through the liquid phase.
Diffusion of water through a selectively permeable membrane.
Movement of particles from high to low concentration.
Movement of substances against concentration gradient using energy.
Movement of substances without using cellular energy.
A large region characterized by distinctive climate and organisms.
The gradual change in species composition of a community over time.
The maximum population size an environment can sustain.
The hunting and consumption of one organism by another.
A close relationship between two different species.
The frequency at which mutations occur in a population.
Random changes in allele frequencies in a population.
The sum of all genetic information in a population.
A principle stating that allele frequencies remain constant without evolution.
A trait that improves an organism's survival or reproduction.
The evolutionary process by which new species arise.
Process where organisms with favorable traits reproduce more.
Human-directed breeding for desired traits.
Evolution of similar traits in unrelated species in similar environments.
Evolution where species become more different over time.
The study of the distribution of organisms across Earth.
A layer of sedimentary rock.
The study of ancient life through fossils.
Method of determining age using radioactive decay.
Time for half the atoms in a radioactive sample to decay.
The largest division of geologic time.
A major division of geologic time within an eon.
A division of geologic time within an era.
A subdivision of a geological period.
The study of mountain formation and characteristics.
The formation and movement of glaciers.
The maximum amount of water vapor air can hold at a given temperature.
The temperature at which water vapor becomes saturated.
Circular movement of fluids caused by heating and cooling.
Fast-moving river of air in the upper atmosphere.
Regions of high or low atmospheric pressure.
The boundary between different air masses.
Change in frequency of waves due to relative motion.
Amplification of vibrations at the natural frequency.
The meeting and combining of two waves.
The bending of waves around obstacles.

Math.definition: A whole number that can be positive, negative, or zero.
A number that represents a part of a whole or a part of a set.
A number that uses a decimal point to show a value smaller than one.
A ratio that compares a number to 100.
A comparison of two quantities by division.
An equation stating that two ratios are equivalent.
A mathematical statement that shows two expressions are equal.
The number that is multiplied by a variable in an algebraic expression.
A mathematical phrase that can contain numbers, variables, and operations.
A mathematical statement that compares two expressions using greater than, less than, or equal to symbols.
A measure of the steepness of a line, found by the ratio of rise over run.
An equation in the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, and c are constants and a ≠ 0.
A function whose graph is a straight line.
A formula that relates the side lengths of a right triangle: a² + b² = c².
The average of a set of numbers, found by adding the numbers and dividing by how many there are.
The middle value in an ordered set of numbers.
The number that appears most often in a set of data.
The difference between the highest and lowest values in a data set.
The likelihood that an event will occur, expressed as a ratio, fraction, or percent.
A number that divides another number evenly.
A whole number greater than 1 that has exactly two factors: 1 and itself.
A whole number greater than 1 that has more than two factors.
The total distance around the outside of a shape.
The amount of surface covered by a shape.
The amount of space a three-dimensional object occupies.
The distance around a circle.
A small number written above and to the right of a base number that shows how many times the base is multiplied by itself.
The rules that tell you the correct sequence to evaluate a mathematical expression (PEMDAS).
Distance of a number from zero on the number line.
Multiplicative inverse of a number (a * 1/a = 1).
Rate with a denominator of one (e.g., miles per hour).
Linear equation form y = mx + b.
Linear equation form y - y1 = m(x - x1).
Linear equation form Ax + By = C.
Relation assigning exactly one output to each input.
Set of all input values for a function.
Set of all output values for a function.
Number not expressible as a fraction; non-repeating decimal.
Coordinates (x, y) locating a point.
Plane defined by perpendicular x and y axes.
Graph showing relationship between paired data.
Line best approximating a data set's trend.
Average distance of each data point from the mean.
Arrangement where order matters.
Selection where order does not matter.
Principal × Rate × Time.
Interest added to principal causing exponential growth.
Original amount invested or borrowed.
Figures with equal angles and proportional sides.
Figures identical in size and shape.
Slide of a figure without rotation.
Turn of a figure around a point.
Flip of a figure across a line.
Resizing a figure proportionally from a center point.
Distance from circle center to edge.
Distance across circle through center (2r).
Triangle with one 90° angle.
Longest side of a right triangle.
Value which produces original when squared.
Number multiplied by itself three times.
Number which produces original when cubed.
Inequality containing a linear expression.
Two or more equations with shared variables.
Values satisfying all equations in a system.
Solve system by replacing a variable with an expression.
Solve system by combining equations to remove a variable.
Percent increase or decrease from original value.
Shape formed by combining simpler shapes.
Sequence with constant difference between consecutive terms.
Sequence with constant ratio between consecutive terms.
Probability based on trials or experiments.
Probability based on all possible outcomes.
Graph summarizing data using quartiles.
Difference between Q3 and Q1 (middle 50%).
Data point far from the rest of a set.
A polynomial with a single term.
A polynomial with exactly two terms.
A polynomial with exactly three terms.
An expression containing multiple terms with variables and exponents.
The highest power of a variable in a polynomial.
Process of dividing one polynomial by another.
Break a polynomial into simpler multiplying factors.
A fraction containing polynomials.
A line that a graph approaches but never reaches.
The turning point of a parabola.
U-shaped curve formed by a quadratic function.
Special point used in the geometric definition of a parabola.
Line used in the geometric definition of a parabola.
An oval-shaped curve with two focal points.
Two curved lines that mirror each other, forming a U shape.
The exponent to which a base must be raised to get a number.
A function where the variable is in the exponent.
A function that reverses the effect of another function.
Combining two functions by feeding the output of one into another.
Repeating a process or function multiple times.
A rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns.
A special value calculated from a square matrix.
A matrix that when multiplied by the original produces identity matrix.
A quantity with both magnitude and direction.
A quantity with only magnitude, no direction.
Absolute value or magnitude of a number or vector.
Horizontal line used in division to group terms.
Standard deviation divided by the mean, expressed as a percentage.
The average of the squared deviations from the mean.
A measure of how spread out data values are from the mean.
Number of standard deviations a value is from the mean.
Values dividing a data set into four equal parts.
Value below which a percentage of data falls.
Table showing the frequency of data values.
Bar graph showing frequency distribution.
Display of data showing distribution and individual values.
Multiply numerators and denominators diagonally in a proportion.
Smallest number divisible by all given numbers.
Largest number that divides all given numbers evenly.
Reduce an expression to its simplest form.
Smallest number that all denominators divide into evenly.

Reasoning Through Language Arts (RLA).definition: The central point or most important concept that an author wants the reader to understand.
Information that explains, proves, or enhances the main idea.
A conclusion reached by using evidence from the text and your own reasoning.
The author's attitude toward the subject or audience.
The underlying message or lesson the author wants to convey.
A sentence that states the main point or argument of an essay.
The sentence that expresses the main idea of a paragraph.
A word or phrase that connects ideas and helps writing flow smoothly.
Facts, examples, or details used to support a claim.
A statement or position that requires support.
An opposing viewpoint that challenges the writer's claim.
The specific group of readers or listeners a text is written for.
The reason why an author writes a text: to inform, persuade, entertain, or explain.
Words or expressions that go beyond literal meaning, such as metaphors and similes.
A comparison between two unlike things without using like or as.
A comparison between two unlike things using the words like or as.
The emotional or cultural meaning attached to a word.
The literal, dictionary definition of a word.
Hints within a sentence or paragraph that help the reader determine the meaning of an unfamiliar word.
Improving a draft by adding, removing, or rearranging ideas for clarity and effectiveness.
Correcting grammar, spelling, and punctuation errors in a draft.
Reviewing a final draft carefully to catch small errors before publishing.
Writing that aims to convince the reader to accept a viewpoint or take a specific action.
Writing that tells a story with characters, setting, and plot.
Nonfiction writing that provides facts about a topic.
The perspective from which a story is told.
A storytelling perspective in which the narrator is a character in the story and uses words like I and we.
A storytelling perspective where the narrator is outside the story and uses words like he, she, or they.
A text structure that presents events in the order they happened.
A text structure that explains why something happens and the result of it.
Repetition of initial consonant sounds in nearby words.
Giving human traits to non-human objects or ideas.
Deliberate exaggeration for emphasis.
Pair of contradictory words (e.g., jumbo shrimp).
Restate text in your own words while keeping meaning.
Condense main ideas without details.
Two or more sentences incorrectly joined.
Incomplete sentence missing subject or predicate.
Rule that subjects and verbs must match in number.
Word replacing a noun.
Noun a pronoun refers to.
Subject performs the action.
Subject receives the action.
Using same grammatical pattern for related ideas.
Group of words with a subject and verb.
Clause that can stand alone.
Clause that cannot stand alone.
Using different sentence patterns for effect.
Claim supported by evidence and reasoning.
Unfair preference toward one side.
Statement proven true.
Personal belief not provable.
Casual language for familiar audience.
Objective, professional language.
Reference giving credit to source.
Using others' words or ideas without credit.
Direct connection of evidence to claim.
Trustworthiness of a source.
Surrounding words or situation clarifying meaning.
Non-literal meaning expressed by figures of speech.
Exact dictionary meaning.
Conversation between characters.
Time and place of a story.
Sequence of events in a story.
Struggle between opposing forces.
Outcome of the conflict.
Hints of future events.
Scene showing past events.
Contrast between expectation and reality.
Use of symbols to represent ideas.
Descriptive language appealing to senses.
The main character in a story.
A character opposing the protagonist.
A character that changes throughout a story.
A character that remains unchanged throughout a story.
A character with complex, realistic qualities.
A character that is simple with few distinctive qualities.
Introduction providing background information.
Events building tension toward climax.
The turning point and most intense moment of a story.
Events following climax leading to resolution.
Final resolution after climax.
A play on words using multiple meanings.
Substituting the name of one thing for another related to it.
A figure of speech where part represents whole or vice versa.
Representing something as less important than it is.
The feeling or atmosphere created by a text.
The distinctive way a writer uses language and expresses ideas.
Choice and use of words in writing.
The arrangement of words and phrases to create sentences.
The style of language appropriate for a specific situation.
The art of persuasive speaking or writing.
Appeal to credibility or character.
Appeal to emotion.
Appeal to logic and reason.
A flaw in reasoning that undermines an argument.
Attacking the person rather than their argument.
Misrepresenting an opponent's argument to refute it.
A broad statement based on specific examples.
Comparison between two different things showing similarities.
Placing contrasting elements side by side.
Indirect reference to another work or historical event.
A phrase or expression with meaning different from individual words.
An overused phrase or expression.
A category of literature with shared characteristics.
Literature based on imagination rather than fact.
Literature based on facts and real events.
Literary work using language for emotional and aesthetic effect.
Written or spoken language in ordinary form.
Literature written for performance on stage.
Drama dealing with serious or disastrous events.
Drama written to amuse and entertain.
Short prose composition on a specific topic.
Narrative account based on writer's personal experience.
Account of someone's life written by another person.
Account of one's own life written by oneself.
A 14-line poem with specific rhyme scheme.
A three-line poem with syllable pattern 5-7-5.
A grouped set of lines in a poem.
Poetry or metrical writing.
The rhythmic pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables.
The pattern of rhymes at ends of lines.
Poetry without regular rhythm or rhyme.
Poetry written in unrhymed iambic pentameter.

Social Studies.definition: A system of government in which citizens hold the power to make decisions through voting.
A form of government in which citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf.
A written plan that outlines the structure, powers, and limits of a government.
A change or addition to a legal or governmental document, such as the U.S. Constitution.
A system of government in which power is divided between a national government and state governments.
The division of government responsibilities into distinct branches to prevent any one branch from becoming too powerful.
A system that allows each branch of government to limit the powers of the other branches.
The right to vote in political elections.
The rights of citizens to political and social freedom and equality.
The development of industries in a country or region on a wide scale.
The growth of cities and the movement of people from rural areas to urban centers.
The system by which goods and services are produced, distributed, and consumed.
A general increase in prices and a decrease in the purchasing value of money.
The total value of all goods and services produced in a country during a specific time period.
The relationship between the amount of a product available and the desire of buyers for it, which affects price.
An original document or firsthand account created at the time of an event.
A document or account that interprets or analyzes primary sources.
The 19th-century belief that the United States was destined to expand across the North American continent.
The period after the U.S. Civil War when southern states were reorganized and reintegrated into the Union.
A severe worldwide economic downturn that took place during the 1930s.
The period of political tension and military rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union after World War II.
The first ten amendments to the U.S. Constitution that protect individual liberties.
The branch of government responsible for making laws.
The branch of government responsible for enforcing laws.
The branch of government responsible for interpreting laws and administering justice.
A form of government in which a single person, such as a king or queen, rules for life.
A tax imposed on imported goods.
A formal agreement between two or more countries.
Movement of African Americans to northern cities (1910–1970).
Programs addressing Great Depression under FDR.
Nonviolent refusal to obey unjust laws.
Movement to end slavery.
Formal approval of a document or amendment.
Biased information used to shape opinion.
Policy of avoiding foreign alliances.
Increasing interconnectedness of economies and cultures.
Spending exceeding revenue.
Revenue exceeding spending.
Plan for income and expenditures.
Government order restricting trade.
System of raising money for public needs.
Era of rapid industrial growth beginning in 18th century.
1863 order freeing slaves in Confederate states.
Granted citizenship and equal protection.
Prohibited denying vote based on race.
Granted women voting rights.
Process used to elect U.S. President.
Advisory heads of executive departments.
Highest U.S. court.
Court power to declare laws unconstitutional.
Fair treatment through justice system.
Freedom from oppressive control.
Citizen responsibility to participate.
Inherent rights (life, liberty, property).
Government ruled by a small group.
Government under one absolute ruler.
System seeking complete control over life.
Separation of groups by race or other trait.
Annual plan of government revenues and spending.
Basic rights and freedoms for all people.
Economic system based on private ownership and free markets.
Economic system with collective or state ownership of production.
Political ideology seeking classless, stateless society.
Formal procedure for changing the Constitution.
System and procedures for holding elections.
Organized group sharing common political goals.
Involving or supported by two political parties.
Person attempting to influence legislation on behalf of interests.
Person currently holding a political office.
Organized effort to win an election.
Set of principles and policies of a political party.
Official representing their country's interests abroad.
Negotiation and conduct of relations between nations.
Power of a state to govern itself and make decisions.
Not aligned with either side in a conflict.
Formal agreement between nations for mutual benefit.
Economic or political penalties against a nation.
Policy of extending a nation's power through colonization.
Establishment and maintenance of colonies by foreign powers.
Devotion to the interests of one's own nation.
Spread of cultural beliefs and practices between groups.
Movement of people from one place to another.
Hostile treatment of a person or group.
Deliberate attempt to destroy an ethnic or cultural group.
Person fleeing persecution or danger.
Protection granted to refugees by a nation.
Unjust treatment based on group membership.
Negative preconceived notion about a group.
Generalized, often inaccurate belief about a group.
Ability to read and write.
Process of teaching and learning.
Basic systems and facilities supporting a society.
Materials supplied by nature useful to humans.
Protection and preservation of natural resources.
Meeting present needs without harming future generations.
Safeguarding nature and ecosystems.
Energy source formed from ancient organic material.
Energy from sources that naturally replenish.
Long-term shift in global temperatures and weather patterns.
Temporary economic decline.
Extended severe economic downturn.
Condition of being without a job.
Lowest hourly wage employers legally pay workers.
Exchange of goods and services between nations.
Goods brought into a country from abroad.
Goods sent from one country to another.
Money in circulation in a country.
Percentage increase in overall prices over time.
Place where shares of companies are bought and sold.
Debt security issued by governments or corporations.
Money committed to earn future financial returns.
Profit distributed to shareholders.
Exclusive control of a product or service by one entity.
Legislation preventing unfair business practices.
Government rule controlling conduct or practice.
Organized action by workers for better conditions.
Organization of workers advocating for their rights.
Work stoppage by employees seeking concessions.
Negotiation between employer and organized workers.
Settlement where each side gives up something.
